title: Penalty Card System
description: Advanced strategy: understand how discarded cards affect your draws.

sections.title: What are Penalty Cards?
sections.content:
A penalty card is a card you discard that would have helped complete a draw. When you discard a card of a suit you're drawing to, you reduce your chances of hitting.

For example: If you're holding 3 hearts and drawing, discarding another heart means there's one less heart in the deck to catch.

sections.title: When Penalties Matter
sections.content:
Penalty cards affect close decisions. When two plays have similar EV, the penalty from discarded cards can tip the balance.

The most common penalty situations:
• High card vs 4-to-straight
• Two high cards vs 4-to-inside-straight
• 3-to-royal vs 4-to-flush

sections.title: Flush Penalty
sections.content: You have a 4-to-straight with a flush penalty card.

exampleHand.explanation: Hold just the Ace. The 5h is a penalty card - if you hold 5-6-7-8, you're discarding a heart that could help a future flush draw. In this case, the Ace alone is better.

sections.title: Straight Penalty
sections.content: Does holding more high cards create straight penalties?

exampleHand.explanation: Hold J-Q only, not T-J-Q. The Ten creates a straight penalty - it blocks potential straights with the remaining cards. J-Q gives you more flexibility.

sections.title: The Rule of Thumb
sections.content: When deciding between high cards, avoid cards that create straight or flush penalties. In close decisions, fewer held cards with no penalties can beat more held cards with penalties.

sections.title: Royal Flush Penalty
sections.content: Should you hold the Ace or King?

exampleHand.explanation: Hold the Ace alone. The King would block K-high straight possibilities and create a royal penalty in clubs. The Ace is more flexible.

sections.title: Suited vs Unsuited High Cards
sections.content: Two high cards - suited or unsuited makes a difference!

exampleHand.explanation: Hold J-Q suited. Suited high cards are always better than unsuited because you maintain flush and royal flush potential.

sections.title: The 3-to-Royal Decision
sections.content:
When you have a 3-to-royal and other options:

• 3-to-royal usually beats 2 unsuited high cards
• 3-to-royal can lose to a 4-flush
• Check for flush penalties in the discards

The cards you throw away matter!

sections.title: 3-to-Royal vs High Cards
sections.content: Should you keep the 3-to-royal or split it?

exampleHand.explanation: Hold T-J-Q of hearts (3-to-royal). Don't add the King - it creates penalties and doesn't improve your royal draw.
Hold the 4-flush. The Ace of hearts doesn't help the flush, and the 4-flush has better EV than a single Ace.

sections.title: Penalty Summary
sections.content:
• Flush penalty: Discarding a card in your draw suit
• Straight penalty: Discarding a card that blocks straights
• Royal penalty: Discarding a royal-eligible card

In close decisions, avoid creating penalties when possible.

practiceHands.explanation: Hold just the Ace. The 4c creates a flush penalty.
Hold A-K. Adding the Queen creates straight penalties.
Hold the 4-flush. It beats the unsuited King.
Hold J-Q. Don't include T or K - they create penalties.
Hold just the Ace. K creates a royal penalty in hearts.
Hold J-Q. The T and K create penalties for this hand.
Hold the 4-flush. The unsuited King is not worth keeping.
